{{good article}} {{Infobox event | title = March for Science Portland | image = March for Science Portland logo.jpg | image_size = | image_upright = | image_alt = | caption = Promotional artwork for the event | native_name = | native_name_lang = | time = 10am – 4pm | duration = | date = {{start date|2017|04|22}} | venue = [[Tom McCall Waterfront Park]] | location = [[Portland, Oregon]], U.S. | coordinates = <!-- {{coord|LAT|LON|region:XXXX_type:event|display=inline,title}} --> | also_known_as = {{Flatlist| * March for Science PDX * Portland March for Science }} | type = [[Demonstration (protest)|Protest march]] | theme = | cause = | first_reporter = | budget = | patron = <!-- or |patrons= --> | organizers = Portland Science Advocates | filmed_by = | participants = Thousands – 10,000+<ref name=KOIN/><ref name=Vespa/> | outcome = | arrests = | url = | website = | notes = }} The '''March for Science Portland''' (also known as the '''March for Science PDX''' and '''Portland March for Science''')<ref name="PSA">{{cite web |title=March for Science Portland, OR |url=https://www.sciencemarchpdx.com |publisher=Portland Science Advocates |accessdate=April 22, 2017 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20170422105122/https://www.sciencemarchpdx.com/ |archivedate=April 22, 2017 |df= }}</ref><ref name="XS">{{cite web|title=Donate to the March For Science PDX! |url=http://xerces.org/sciencemarchpdx/ |publisher=[[Xerces Society]] |accessdate=April 22, 2017 |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20170425085831/http://xerces.org/sciencemarchpdx/ |archivedate=April 25, 2017 }}</ref> was a protest held in [[Portland, Oregon]]. This local protest was part of the [[March for Science]], a series of rallies and marches in [[Washington, D.C.]] and over 600 cities across the world on April 22, 2017 ([[Earth Day]]). Portland Science Advocates organized the march in support of science and to protest President [[Donald Trump]]'s plan to cut funding for the [[United States Environmental Protection Agency|Environmental Protection Agency]] and the [[National Institutes of Health]]. Funding for the event, which cost approximately $30,000, was [[crowdsourcing|crowdsourced]].
Amid rainy weather, thousands of people attended the demonstration, gathering at a rally at [[Tom McCall Waterfront Park]] before marching 44 blocks of [[downtown Portland]]. Speakers included [[Earl Blumenauer]], [[Suzanne Bonamici]], and [[Elizabeth Steiner Hayward]]. Organizations that promoted the protest included the [[Audubon Society of Portland]], [[Oregon Environmental Council]], [[Oregon Health & Science University]], and [[Xerces Society]]. Reporters noted organizers' attempts to create a political yet nonpartisan atmosphere, and participants' public criticism of Trump. The event featured activities for children and was described as having a [[family-friendly]] atmosphere.
==Background== ===Organizers and motivation=== [[File:March for Science, PDX, 2017 - 29.jpg|thumb|right|Handmade sign with a variation on "[[Make America Great Again]]"]]
Portland's March for Science was organized by Portland Science Advocates.<ref name=PSA/><ref name=XS/> The group was composed of people with backgrounds in various disciplines, including Jackie Wirz, an assistant dean at [[Oregon Health & Science University]], and a store clerk with a passion for science and writing.<ref name="Campuzano">{{cite news|last1=Campuzano|first1=Eder|title=Portland's March for Science: This one's for the kids|url=http://www.oregonlive.com/portland/index.ssf/2017/04/portland_science_march_earth_day_protest.html|accessdate=April 22, 2017|work=[[The Oregonian]]|date=April 22, 2017|publisher=[[Advance Publications]]|issn=8750-1317|location=Portland, Oregon}}</ref> The event's steering committee included co-chairs Curt Waltman and Wirz; additionally, Rich Hatfield served as communications committee co-chair and Sumi Malik, a transportation planner for [[CH2M Hill]],<ref name=Humanize/> served as community outreach co-chair.<ref name="Guest">{{cite news|title=Marching for science that's vital to Oregon's economy, environment and health (Guest opinion)|url=http://www.oregonlive.com/opinion/index.ssf/2017/04/marching_for_science_thats_vit.html|accessdate=April 23, 2017|work=The Oregonian|date=April 21, 2017|first1=Curt|last1=Waltman|first2=Jackie|last2=Wirz}}</ref> Alex Conley was also an organizer.<ref name=Humanize/> The organizers met through the event's Facebook page, which was launched in February 2017, and sought advice from the organizers of the [[Women's March on Portland]], which was held in January 2017.<ref name="Humanize">{{cite news|last1=Campuzano|first1=Eder|title=Portland's March for Science: 'We want to humanize scientists'|url=http://www.oregonlive.com/portland/index.ssf/2017/04/portland_march_for_science.html|accessdate=April 25, 2017|work=The Oregonian|date=April 16, 2017}}</ref>
Organizers wanted to support science and protest [[Donald Trump]]'s plan to cut funding for the [[United States Environmental Protection Agency|Environmental Protection Agency]] and the [[National Institutes of Health]]. The event was also to protest Trump's threat to withdraw from the [[Paris Agreement]] and decrease funding for scientific research and [[K–12]] science programs,<ref name=Humanize/><ref name="KUOW">{{cite web|title=Looming Budget Cuts Put Scientists In Limbo|url=http://kuow.org/post/looming-budget-cuts-put-scientists-limbo|publisher=[[KUOW-FM]]|accessdate=April 23, 2017|date=April 21, 2017|location=Seattle}}</ref> among other policies.<ref name="Oregonian">{{cite news|url=http://www.oregonlive.com/portland/index.ssf/2017/04/traffic_delays_portland_march_for_science_earth_day.html|accessdate=April 22, 2017|work=The Oregonian|date=April 21, 2017|first=Eder|last=Campuzano|title=Prepare for traffic, delays downtown during Portland's March for Science on Saturday}}</ref> Prior to the march, Waltman and Wirz wrote a guest column in ''[[The Oregonian]]'', where they noted Oregon's achievements in science, and encouraged people to "stand up for science".<ref name=Guest/> They said, "We stand in support of scientific inquiry, researchers, availability of data and evidence-based policy", and invited people who "love" science to participate.<ref name=Guest/>
===Preparation and planning===
Funding for the event, which cost approximately $30,000, was crowdsourced. Obtaining a permit to host the event at the park cost $3,000.<ref name=Humanize/> Monetary donations were accepted, and merchandise sales also funded the demonstrations. Funds were transferred through the [[Xerces Society]].<ref name=Humanize/> Portland Science Advocates was established as a nonprofit organization for members to continue the demonstration's mission after the march.<ref name=Humanize/>
Prior to the march, organizers surveyed [[Tom McCall Waterfront Park]] and posted flyers about the event in the surrounding area.<ref name=Humanize/> They emphasized that all people were invited to participate, not just scientists,<ref name="Guide">{{cite news|title=Guide to Portland's March for Science Saturday, expected to be thousands strong |url=http://katu.com/news/local/guide-portland-march-for-science-downtown-speaker-size-number-signs |accessdate=April 22, 2017 |publisher=[[KATU]] |date=April 21, 2017 |location=Portland, Oregon |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20170621060237/http://katu.com/news/local/guide-portland-march-for-science-downtown-speaker-size-number-signs |archivedate=June 21, 2017 }}</ref> and anticipated participation by approximately 10,000 demonstrators.<ref name="Vespa">{{cite news|last1=Vespa|first1=Maggie|title=Thousands March for Science in Portland|url=http://www.kgw.com/news/politics/thousands-march-for-science-in-portland/433419583|accessdate=April 23, 2017|publisher=[[KGW]]|date=April 22, 2017|location=Portland, Oregon}}</ref><ref name=Humanize/> Nearly 7,000 had committed to attending the event on its [[Facebook]] page.<ref name="Thomas">{{cite news|last1=Thomas |first1=Keaton |title=Thousands take to the streets of downtown Portland for Earth Day 'March for Science' |url=http://katu.com/news/local/thousands-expected-in-downtown-portland-for-earth-day-march-for-science |accessdate=April 22, 2017 |publisher=KATU |date=April 22, 2017 |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20170426085522/http://katu.com/news/local/thousands-expected-in-downtown-portland-for-earth-day-march-for-science |archivedate=April 26, 2017 }}</ref> Organizers planned to use drones to help estimate the crowd size.<ref name=Humanize/>
==Demonstration== [[File:March For Science PDX (34250021585).jpg|thumb|left|Protesters marching south along Naito Parkway]]
More than a thousand people had gathered by the time the rally began at 10:00{{nbsp}}am at Tom McCall Waterfront Park,<ref name=Thomas/><ref name="Henriksen">{{cite news|last1=Henriksen |first1=Erik |title=Give a Shit About Science, Progress, and Equality? Then Don't Miss the March for Science |url=http://www.portlandmercury.com/blogtown/2017/04/21/18964756/give-a-shit-about-science-progress-and-equality-then-dont-miss-tomorrows-march-for-science |accessdate=April 22, 2017 |work=[[The Portland Mercury]] |publisher=Index Publishing |date=April 21, 2017 |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20170427003703/http://www.portlandmercury.com/blogtown/2017/04/21/18964756/give-a-shit-about-science-progress-and-equality-then-dont-miss-tomorrows-march-for-science |archivedate=April 27, 2017 }}</ref> near the [[Morrison Bridge]].<ref name=Oregonian/><ref name=Guide/> Six business leaders,<ref name=Campuzano/> innovators, politicians, and scientists spoke at the event.<ref name=Thomas/> Politicians included [[United States House of Representatives|U.S. Representative]] for {{ushr|OR|3}}, [[Earl Blumenauer]], U.S. Representative for [[Oregon's 1st congressional district|the state's 1st congressional district]], [[Suzanne Bonamici]],<ref>{{Cite journal|url=http://www.sciencemag.org/news/2017/04/congress-march-science-democratic-event |title=For Congress, March for Science is a Democratic event |work=[[Science (journal)|Science]] |first=Jeffrey |last=Mervis |date=April 20, 2017 |accessdate=April 23, 2017 |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20170421061226/http://www.sciencemag.org/news/2017/04/congress-march-science-democratic-event |archivedate=April 21, 2017 }}</ref> and [[Elizabeth Steiner Hayward]], who serves as a [[Democratic Party (Oregon)|Democratic]] member of the [[Oregon State Senate]] for the 17th District.<ref name=KOIN/><ref name=Speakers>{{cite web |title=Speakers |url=https://www.sciencemarchpdx.com/take-action |publisher=Portland Science Advocates |accessdate=April 22, 2017 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20170427003701/https://www.sciencemarchpdx.com/take-action |archivedate=April 27, 2017 |df= }}</ref>
Blumenauer referred to the Trump administration in his speech, saying, "We have failed in the political process because they've made science partisan. They've undermined the credibility and confidence that people have, for example in science, dealing with climate."<ref name=Vespa/> He also spoke about the importance of evidence-based decision making.<ref name=Hewitt/> In her speech, Bonamici said science should not be a partisan issue, and told the crowd: "We are going to go back to Washington, D.C., with all of you in our mind — this beautiful sea of science supporters, and fight for research, fight for science, fight for clean air, fight for clean water, and fight for our planet. So stay engaged, please. This is just the beginning."<ref name="Hewitt">{{cite news|last1=Hewitt |first1=Lyndsey |title=Thousands in Portland march in name of science |url=http://portlandtribune.com/pt/9-news/355607-235575-thousands-in-portland-march-in-name-of-science- |accessdate=April 25, 2017 |work=[[Portland Tribune]] |date=April 22, 2017 |publisher=[[Pamplin Media Group]] |oclc=46708462 |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20170426152228/http://portlandtribune.com/pt/9-news/355607-235575-thousands-in-portland-march-in-name-of-science- |archivedate=April 26, 2017 }}</ref>
The other speakers included Xerces Society senior conservation biologist Rich Hatfield, [[Intel]] educator and innovation manager Shashi Jain, and Gabe Sheoships, a citizen of the [[Cayuse people|Cayuse]] and [[Walla Walla people|Walla Walla]] tribes of the [[Confederated Tribes of the Umatilla Indian Reservation]], who serves as education director for Friends of Tryon Creek, and is an adjunct faculty member at [[Portland State University]].<ref name=Thomas/><ref name=Speakers/>
[[File:March for Science, PDX, 2017 - 28.jpg|thumb|right|Marchers returning to the park]]
At about 11:00{{nbsp}}am,<ref name=Oregonian/> protesters began marching south along Naito Parkway.<ref name=Thomas/> They navigated a 44-block portion of downtown,<ref name=Oregonian/> before returning to the park around noon for a "Science Expo" and "Kid Zone", as well as live music.<ref name=KOIN/><ref name=Vespa/><ref name=Henriksen/> The route was identical to the one used during the [[Women's March on Portland]]; participants followed Naito to Jefferson Street, to Fourth Avenue, to Pine Street, then revisited Tom McCall Waterfront Park.<ref name=Campuzano/><ref name=Oregonian/> Family-friendly educational booths and vendors were stationed near the park's Battleship Oregon Memorial.<ref name=Oregonian/><ref name="OPB">{{cite news|last1=Solomon |first1=Molly |title=Thousands Hit the Streets for Portland's March for Science |url=http://www.opb.org/news/article/portland-march-for-science-earth-day/ |accessdate=April 23, 2017 |publisher=[[Oregon Public Broadcasting]] |date=April 22, 2017 |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20170629092350/http://www.opb.org/news/article/portland-march-for-science-earth-day/ |archivedate=June 29, 2017 }}</ref> The demonstration ended at about 4:00{{nbsp}}pm.<ref name=Oregonian/>
Amid rainy weather,<ref name=Hewitt/><ref>{{cite journal|title=Live updates from the global March for Science: Portland marchers brave the rain for science |journal=Science |date=April 21, 2017 |url=http://www.sciencemag.org/news/2017/04/march-science-live-coverage |accessdate=April 22, 2017 |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20170425230132/http://www.sciencemag.org/news/2017/04/march-science-live-coverage |archivedate=April 25, 2017 }}</ref> thousands of people attended the demonstration.<ref name="KOIN">{{cite news|title=Thousands March for Science in Portland on Saturday |url=http://koin.com/2017/04/21/15k-may-march-for-science-in-portland-on-saturday/ |accessdate=April 22, 2017 |publisher=[[KOIN]] |date=April 21, 2017 |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20170426153240/http://koin.com/2017/04/21/15k-may-march-for-science-in-portland-on-saturday/ |archivedate=April 26, 2017 }}</ref><ref name=Campuzano/><ref name=OPB/> Some crowd estimates "far exceeded" the anticipated 10,000 participants.<ref name=Vespa/> Many protesters wore science-themed costumes, such as bio suits, [[space suit]]s, and white lab coats.<ref name=Hewitt/> The city experienced increased traffic because of street and bridge closures for the march, and other events.<ref name=Oregonian/><ref name=Guide/><ref name=Thomas/>
==Partnerships== [[File:March for Science, PDX, 2017 - 02.jpg|thumb|right|Protesters carrying signs, including one made by [[The Nature Conservancy]].]]
The march was endorsed by the [[Audubon Society of Portland]],<ref name="ASP">{{cite web|title=March for Science|url=http://audubonportland.org/about/events/march-for-science|publisher=[[Audubon Society of Portland]]|accessdate=April 22, 2017}}</ref> Oregon Health & Science University,<ref name="OHSU">[[Oregon Health & Science University]]: * {{cite web|title=OHSU rallies for science |url=http://www.ohsu.edu/blogs/researchnews/2017/04/14/ohsu-rallies-for-science/ |accessdate=April 22, 2017 |publisher=Oregon Health & Science University }} * {{cite web|last1=Hersh |first1=William |title=Why I'm participating in the March for Science |url=https://news.ohsu.edu/2017/04/18/why-im-participating-in-the-march-for-science |accessdate=April 22, 2017 |publisher=Oregon Health & Science University |date=April 18, 2017 |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20170430051200/https://news.ohsu.edu/2017/04/18/why-im-participating-in-the-march-for-science |archivedate=April 30, 2017 }}</ref> and Xerces Society,<ref name=XS/><ref name=KUOW/> and promoted by the Democratic Party of Washington County,<ref>{{cite web|title=Portland March for Science|url=http://www.washcodems.org/events/portland-march-science|publisher=Democratic Party of Washington County|accessdate=April 22, 2017}}</ref> [[Oregon Environmental Council]],<ref name="OEC">{{cite web|title=March for Science – Oregon Locations|url=http://www.oeconline.org/march-for-science-oregon-locations/|publisher=[[Oregon Environmental Council]]|accessdate=April 22, 2017}}</ref> Portland State University's biology department,<ref name=OPB/><ref>{{cite web|title=March for Science – Walk in Solidarity with the PSU Biology Department! Saturday, April 22, 2017 – 9:15am|url=https://www.pdx.edu/event/march-science-walk-solidarity-psu-biology-department?delta=0|publisher=[[Portland State University]]|accessdate=April 22, 2017}}</ref> and Rose City Astronomers.<ref name="RCA">{{cite web|title=Join the March for Science!|url=http://www.rosecityastronomers.net/calendar/2017/4/22/rca-plans-to-join-march-for-science|publisher=Rose City Astronomers|accessdate=April 22, 2017}}</ref>
The [[Center for Biological Diversity]] also issued a press release confirming some of its scientists planned to march in Portland and other cities throughout the United States.<ref>{{cite web|title=Scientists to March Against Trump's Alternative Facts, Climate Denial |url=https://www.biologicaldiversity.org/news/press_releases/2017/march-for-science-04-20-2017.php |publisher=[[Center for Biological Diversity]] |accessdate=April 23, 2017 |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20170421141546/http://www.biologicaldiversity.org/news/press_releases/2017/march-for-science-04-20-2017.php |archivedate=April 21, 2017 }}</ref> The educational nonprofit organization Science Project had a booth at the park.<ref name=OPB/> The [[American Chemical Society]], which publishes ''[[Chemical & Engineering News]]'', supported the parent March for Science demonstration as long as organizers remained nonpartisan; the trade magazine's former editor-in-chief, Rudy Baum, covered the Portland march.<ref>{{cite journal|title=Chemists march for science |journal=[[Chemical & Engineering News]] |url=http://cen.acs.org/articles/95/web/2017/04/Chemists-march-for-science.html |accessdate=April 25, 2017 |publisher=[[American Chemical Society]] |date=April 23, 2017 |first1=Sarah |last1=Everts |first2=Cheryl |last2=Hogue |first3=Lisa |last3=Jarvis |first4=Jyllian |last4=Kemsley |first5=Michael |last5=McCoy |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20170426152457/http://cen.acs.org/articles/95/web/2017/04/Chemists-march-for-science.html |archivedate=April 26, 2017 }}</ref> Portland's Badass Women's Protest Choir, which formed after the [[United States presidential election, 2016|2016 presidential election]], also planned to attend.<ref name="Susim">{{cite news|last1=Susim |first1=Jason |title=Portland's Badass Women's Protest Choir is Performing at the #ICantKeepQuiet Day Flash Mob This Weekend |url=http://www.wweek.com/culture/2017/04/07/portlands-badass-womens-protest-choir-is-performing-at-the-icantkeepquiet-day-flash-mob-this-weekend/ |accessdate=April 25, 2017 |work=[[Willamette Week]] |date=April 7, 2017 |location=Portland, Oregon |publisher=City of Roses Newspapers |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20170426155929/http://www.wweek.com/culture/2017/04/07/portlands-badass-womens-protest-choir-is-performing-at-the-icantkeepquiet-day-flash-mob-this-weekend/ |archivedate=April 26, 2017 }}</ref>
The Audubon Society of Portland organized a sign making party on April 20.<ref name=ASP/>
==Commentary and documentation== Leading up to the event, ''[[The Portland Mercury]]''{{'s}} Erik Henriksen encouraged readers to join the march, writing: "Trump's hostility to science isn't just an attack on humankind's accumulated knowledge—it's an attack on all of us, and its repercussions will affect everyone on Earth, every day, for the rest of our lives. Time to fight back."<ref name=Henriksen/> [[KOIN]] said organizers portrayed the demonstration as "political but not partisan, promoting the understanding of science as well as defending it from various attacks, including proposed U.S. government budget cuts under President Donald Trump".<ref name=KOIN/> Similarly, Maggie Vespa of [[KGW]] said, "Although organizers trumpeted the event's 'nonpartisan' platform, participants in Portland were quick to take aim at President Trump's proposed funding cuts to scientific research agencies."<ref name=Vespa/>
[[File:March For Science PDX (34209711036).jpg|thumb|left|Demonstrators]]
Following the event, ''The Oregonian''{{'s}} Eder Campuzano noted, "unlike so many similar demonstrations — such as January's Women's March, the [[Tax March|Tax Day March]] or several other downtown protests — this one skewed younger".<ref name=Campuzano/> Furthermore, he said of the event's [[family-friendly]] atmosphere: "Demonstrators turned out in droves with their children in tow, a fact many parents attributed to the fact that event organizers had provided a kids' zone near the Battleship Oregon Memorial with educational booths and live music nearby."<ref name=Campuzano/> Lyndsey Hewitt of the ''[[Portland Tribune]]'' noted, "The March for Science's crowd was somewhat calmer than the Women's March, which was an audience electrified, fresh off the heels of President Donald Trump's inauguration... The March for Science, however — announced not long after the Women's March — had a much more focused group of protestors."<ref name=Hewitt/>
One demonstrator, immuno-oncologist and filmmaker Tyler Hulett, documented the march and created the 8-mintute film, ''A Scientist Documents the March for Science''. The film features people "whose lives and careers intersect with science and research", including a woman who believes funding for her cancer research work is being threatened, a couple who is worried about reduced Great Lakes Restoration Initiative funding, and a woman concerned about Portland's unfluoridated water.<ref name="MacMurdo">{{cite news|last1=MacMurdo |first1=Walker |title=Watch a Short Documentary About the Portland March for Science Made by Local Scientist |url=http://www.wweek.com/arts/movies/2017/04/25/watch-a-short-documentary-about-the-portland-march-for-science-made-by-a-portland-scientist/ |accessdate=April 25, 2017 |work=Willamette Week |date=April 25, 2017 |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20170426154552/http://www.wweek.com/arts/movies/2017/04/25/watch-a-short-documentary-about-the-portland-march-for-science-made-by-a-portland-scientist/ |archivedate=April 26, 2017 }}</ref> Hulett wanted to raise awareness about the people involved in scientific research, and said his goal was to "show that many of Portland's doctors and scientists are concerned about the lack of critical thinking coming from both sides of the political aisle".<ref name=MacMurdo/>
==See also== * [[2017 in science]] * [[Environmental politics]] * [[Individual and political action on climate change]] * [[List of 2017 March for Science locations]] * [[List of environmental protests]] * [[March for Science 2018]] * [[Post-truth politics]]

revision.comment: Add: pmc, pmid. Removed parameters. You can [[WP:UCB|use this bot]] yourself. [[WP:DBUG|Report bugs here]]. | [[User:NessieVL|NessieVL]]; [[Category:Planktology]].
revision.text:
'''Microbial symbiosis in marine animals''' was not discovered until 1981.<ref>{{cite journal|last1=Cavanaugh|first1=Colleen|title=Microbial Symbiosis: Patterns of Diversity in the Marine Environment|journal=Integr Comp Biol Integrative and Comparative Biology|date=1994|volume=34|issue=1|pages=79–89|url=http://icb.oxfordjournals.org/content/34/1/79.full.pdf+html|accessdate=May 31, 2015}}</ref> In the time following, [[symbiotic]] relationships between [[marine invertebrates]] and [[chemoautotrophic]] bacteria have been found in a variety of ecosystems, ranging from shallow coastal waters to deep-sea [[hydrothermal vent]]s. The type of marine animal vary greatly, for example, sponges, sea squirts, corals, worms, and algae all host a variety of unique symbionts.<ref>{{cite journal|last1=Li|first1=Zhiyong|title=Advances in Marine Microbial Symbionts in the China Sea and Related Pharmaceutical Metabolites|journal=Marine Drugs|date=2009|volume=7|issue=2|pages=113–129|url=http://www.mdpi.com/1660-3397/7/2/113/htm|accessdate=1 June 2015|doi=10.3390/md7020113|pmid=19597576|pmc=2707038}}</ref> Each symbiotic relationship displays a unique ecological niche, which in turn can lead to entirely new species of host species and symbiont.<ref>{{cite journal|last1=Cavanaugh|first1=Colleen|title=Microbial Symbiosis: Patterns of Diversity in the Marine Environment|journal=Integr Comp Biol Integrative and Comparative Biology|date=1994|volume=34|issue=1|pages=79–89|url=http://icb.oxfordjournals.org/content/34/1/79.full.pdf+html|accessdate=1 June 2015}}</ref>
It is particularly interesting that it took so long to discover the marine microbial symbiosis because nearly every surface submerged in the oceans becomes covered with [[biofilm]],<ref>{{cite journal|last1=Armstrong|first1=Evelyn|last2=Yan|first2=Liming|last3=Boyd|first3=Kenneth|last4=Phillip|first4=Wright|last5=Burgess|first5=J|title=The symbiotic role of marine microbes on living surfaces|journal=Hydrobiologia|date=2001|volume=461|issue=1–3|pages=37–40|doi=10.1023/A:1012756913566}}</ref> including a large number of living organisms. Many marine organisms display symbiotic relationships with microbes. [[Epibiotic]] bacteria have been found to live on crustacean larvae and protect them from fungal infections.<ref>{{cite journal|last1=Armstrong|first1=Evelyn|last2=Yan|first2=Liming|last3=Boyd|first3=Kenneth|last4=Phillip|first4=Wright|last5=Burgess|first5=J|title=The symbiotic role of marine microbes on living surfaces|journal=Hydrobiologia|date=2001|volume=461|issue=1–3|pages=37–40|doi=10.1023/A:1012756913566}}</ref> Other microbes in deep-sea vents have been found to prevent the settlement of barnacles and tunicate larvae.<ref>{{cite journal|last1=Armstrong|first1=Evelyn|last2=Yan|first2=Liming|last3=Boyd|first3=Kenneth|last4=Phillip|first4=Wright|last5=Burgess|first5=J|title=The symbiotic role of marine microbes on living surfaces|journal=Hydrobiologia|date=2001|volume=461|issue=1–3|pages=37–40|doi=10.1023/A:1012756913566}}</ref>
The most notable display of marine symbiotic relationship would be coral. Coral reefs are home to a variety of [[dinoflagellate]] symbiont,<ref>{{cite journal|last1=Baker|first1=Andrew|title=Flexibility and Specificity in Coral-Algal Symbiosis: Diversity, Ecology, and Biogeography of Symbiodinium|journal=Annual Review of Ecology, Evolution, and Systematics|date=200|volume=34|pages=661–689|jstor=30033790|doi=10.1146/annurev.ecolsys.34.011802.132417}}</ref> these symbionts give coral its bright coloring and are vital for the survival of the reef. The symbionts provide the coral with food in exchange for protection. If the waters warm or become too acidic, the symbionts are expelled, the [[Coral bleaching|coral bleaches]] and if conditions persist the coral will die. This in turn leads to the collapse of the entire reef ecosystem.<ref>{{cite journal|last1=Baker|first1=Andrew|title=Flexibility and Specificity in Coral-Algal Symbiosis: Diversity, Ecology, and Biogeography of Symbiodinium|journal=Annual Review of Ecology, Evolution, and Systematics|date=200|volume=34|pages=661–689|jstor=30033790|doi=10.1146/annurev.ecolsys.34.011802.132417}}</ref>
== Microbial biotechnology == Marine invertebrates are the hosts of a wide spectrum of bioactive metabolites, which have vast potential as drugs and research tools.<ref>{{cite journal|last1=Haygood|first1=Margo|last2=Schmidt|first2=Eric|last3=Davidson|first3=Seana|last4=Faulkner|first4=John|title=Microbial Symbionts of Marine Invertebrates: Opportunities for Microbial Biotechnology|journal=J. Mol. Microbiol. Biotechnol.|date=1999|volume=1|issue=1|pages=33–43|url=http://www.horizonpress.com/backlist/jmmb/v/v1/v1n1/06.pdf|accessdate=1 June 2015|pmid=10941782}}</ref> In many cases, microbes aid in or are responsible for marine invertebrates natural products.<ref>{{cite journal|last1=Haygood|first1=Margo|last2=Schmidt|first2=Eric|last3=Davidson|first3=Seana|last4=Faulkner|first4=John|title=Microbial Symbionts of Marine Invertebrates: Opportunities for Microbial Biotechnology|journal=J. Mol. Microbiol. Biotechnol.|date=1999|volume=1|issue=1|pages=33–43|url=http://www.horizonpress.com/backlist/jmmb/v/v1/v1n1/06.pdf|accessdate=1 June 2015|pmid=10941782}}</ref> Certain marine microbes can provide insight into the biosynthesis mechanisms of natural products, which in turn could solve the current limitations on marine drug development.<ref>{{cite journal|last1=Li|first1=Zhiyong|title=Advances in Marine Microbial Symbionts in the China Sea and Related Pharmaceutical Metabolites|journal=Marine Drugs|date=2009|volume=7|issue=2|pages=113–129|url=http://www.mdpi.com/1660-3397/7/2/113/htm|accessdate=1 June 2015|doi=10.3390/md7020113|pmid=19597576|pmc=2707038}}</ref>
== References== {{reflist|25em}}

{{coord|37.9991368|N|23.8178859|E|type:landmark|format=dms|display=title}} [[File:Entrance of Institute of nuclear and particle physics NCSR Demokritos.jpg|300px|right|thumb|Entrance of Institute of nuclear and particle physics NCSR Demokritos]] The '''National Centre of Scientific Research "Demokritos"''' ('''NRCPS'''; {{lang-el|Εθνικό Κέντρο Έρευνας Φυσικών Επιστημών (Ε.Κ.Ε.Φ.Ε.) "Δημόκριτος"}}) is a research center in [[Greece]], employing over 1,000 researchers, engineers, technicians and administrative personnel. It focuses on several fields of natural sciences and engineering and hosts laboratory facilities.
The facilities cover approximately {{convert|150|acres|abbr=off}} of land at [[Aghia Paraskevi]], ten kilometers from the center of [[Athens]], on the northern side of [[Hymettus]] mountain. The buildings cover an area of approximately 35.000 m{{sup|2}} (8.6 acres).
The Centre started its operation in 1959 as an independent division of the public sector under the name ''Nuclear Research Center "Demokritos"'', named in honour of the Greek philosopher [[Democritus]]. In 1985 it was renamed and given self-governing jurisdiction under the auspices of the General Secretariat of Research and Technology. The original objective of the newly created center was the advancement of nuclear research and technology for peaceful purposes. Today, its activities cover several fields of science and engineering.
The NCSR is a self-administered governmental legal entity, under the supervision of the General Secretariat of Research and Technology of the [[Ministry of Education (Greece)|Ministry of Education]].
==Research Institutes== [[File:Nuclear accelerator in NCSR Demokritos.jpg|thumb|right|Ion Accelerator Tandem]] The research activities of the centre are conducted in eight administratively independent institutes:
*Institute of [[Biology]] *Institute of [[Materials Science]] (IMS) *Institute of [[Microelectronics]] *Institute of [[Informatics (academic field)|Informatics]] and [[Telecommunications]] (IIT) *Institute of [[Nuclear technology|Nuclear Technology]] - [[Radiation Protection]] (INT-RP) *Institute of [[Nuclear physics|Nuclear Physics]] *Institute of [[Radioisotopes]] & Radiodiagnostic Products *Institute of [[Physical Chemistry]]
The INT-RP at Demokritos operates Greece's only [[nuclear reactor]], a 5 MW research reactor.
==The Environmental Research Laboratory (EREL)== The EREL is part of the Institute of Nuclear Technology - Radiation Protection (INT-RP) and it is one of the largest scientific research teams in Greece dealing with environmental research. The staff consists of 13 Ph.D. and 5 M.Sc. scientists, 4 Ph.D. students, 1 technician and 1 administrative assistant.
The research and development activities of the EREL include:
*Weather Forecasting *Urban [[air quality]] *[[Emission inventory|Emissions inventories]] *Air quality measurement, analysis and predictions *[[Atmospheric dispersion modeling|Air pollutant dispersion modelling]]<ref>{{cite book|author=Turner, D.B.|title=Workbook of atmospheric dispersion estimates: an introduction to dispersion modeling|edition=2nd|publisher=CRC Press|year=1994|isbn=1-56670-023-X}} [http://www.crcpress.com/shopping_cart/products/product_detail.asp?sku=L1023&parent_id=&pc= www.crcpress.com] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20071105075907/http://www.crcpress.com/shopping_cart/products/product_detail.asp?sku=L1023&parent_id=&pc= |date=2007-11-05 }}</ref><ref>{{cite book|author=Beychok, M.R.|title=[[Fundamentals Of Stack Gas Dispersion]]|edition=4th|publisher=author-published|year=2005|isbn=0-9644588-0-2}} [http://www.air-dispersion.com www.air-dispersion.com]</ref> over terrain of high complexity on local, urban and regional scales. *Transport in porous media and characterization of porous materials *Soil remediation
===The DETRACT atmospheric dispersion modeling system=== The DETRACT [[atmospheric dispersion modelling]] system, developed by the EREL, is an integrated set of modules for modelling air pollution dispersion over highly complex terrain.
==The Media Networks Laboratory== The Laboratory is a part of the “Digital Communications” research programme of the Institute of Informatics and Telecommunications, NCSR “Demokritos”. It is located in the premises of NCSR in Athens, Greece and employs high-qualified research personnel, specialised in networking and multimedia technologies. The laboratory has been active for more than a decade in a number of national and European research projects, following the reputation of the Institute of Informatics and Telecommunication in the global research communities. In this context, it maintains close collaboration with Greek and international partners, both industrial and academic. The research achievements of the laboratory are reflected in a considerable number of publications in journals and conferences.
The lab pioneered in 2001 by developing the first digital television platform to support fully interactive services in Greece (and one of the first ones in Europe).

ΕΚΕΦΕ Δημόκριτος.jpeg|Pathobiology Laboratory File:Εργαστήριο NMR-ΕΚΕΦΕ Δημόκριτος.jpeg|Pathobiology Laboratory File:00048 REP SDR cell culture-41 (0595).jpg|Lab of pathobiology cells and extracellular matrix-Efferent cell culture File:ΕΚΕΦΕ Δημόκριτος Εργαστήριο Παθοβιολογίας κυττάρων και εξωκυττάριου χώρου 3.jpg|Lab of pathobiology cells and extracellular matrix File:ΕΚΕΦΕ Δημόκριτος Εργαστήριο Παθοβιολογίας κυττάρων και εξωκυττάριου χώρου 5.jpg|Lab of pathobiology cells and extracellular matrix File:ΕΚΕΦΕ Δημόκριτος Εργαστήριο Παθοβιολογίας κυττάρων και εξωκυττάριου χώρου 4.jpg|Lab of pathobiology cells and extracellular matrix File:ΕΚΕΦΕ Δημόκριτος Εργαστήριο Συνεστιακό Μικροσκόπιο 2.jpg|Laboratory of Confocal Microscope File:ΕΚΕΦΕ Δημόκριτος Εργαστήριο Συνεστιακό Μικροσκόπιο 1.jpg|Laboratory of Confocal Microscope File:ΕΚΕΦΕ Δημόκριτος Εργαστήριο Μοριακής Διαγνωστικής 5.jpg|Laboratory of Molecular Diagnostics File:ΕΚΕΦΕ Δημόκριτος Εργαστήριο Μοριακής Διαγνωστικής 1.jpg|Laboratory of Molecular Diagnostics File:ΕΚΕΦΕ Δημόκριτος Εργαστήριο Μοριακής Διαγνωστικής 3.jpg|Laboratory of Molecular Diagnostics </gallery></center>

{{Infobox song | name = New York Mining Disaster 1941 | cover = New_York_Mining_Disaster_1941.gif | alt = | border = yes | type = single | artist = [[Bee Gees]] | album = [[Bee Gees' 1st]] | B-side = "[[I Can't See Nobody]]"{{cite web|url=http://www.discogs.com/Bee-Gees-The-New-York-Mining-Disaster-1941/release/2603864 |title=Bee Gees - New York Mining Disaster 1941 |publisher=Discogs |accessdate=13 March 2013}} | released = 14 April 1967 | format = [[7"]] | recorded = {{plainlist|13–16 March 1967|[[IBC Studios]], London}} | studio = | venue = | genre = [[Folk rock]]{{cite book|author=Nicholas Pegg|title=The Complete David Bowie|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=nnO_BgAAQBAJ&pg=PT730|accessdate=25 November 2015|date=2 December 2011|publisher=Titan|isbn=978-0-85768-719-7|page=730}} | length = {{Duration|m=2|s=09}} | label = [[Polydor Records|Polydor]] (United Kingdom, Canada)
[[Atco Records|Atco]] (United States, Mexico)
[[Spin Records (Australian Label)|Spin]] (Australia, New Zealand) | writer = [[Barry Gibb]], [[Robin Gibb]] | producer = [[Robert Stigwood]], [[Ossie Byrne]] | prev_title = Born a Man | prev_year = 1967 | next_title = [[To Love Somebody (song)|To Love Somebody]] | next_year = 1967 | misc = {{Extra music sample|filename=NewYorkMiningDisaster1941.ogg |title="New York Mining Disaster 1941" |Type=single}} }} '''"New York Mining Disaster 1941"''' is the debut American single by the British pop group the [[Bee Gees]], released on 14 April 1967. It was written by [[Barry Gibb|Barry]] and [[Robin Gibb]]. Barring a moderately successful reissue of their Australian single "[[Spicks and Specks (song)|Spicks and Specks]]," it was the first single release of the group's international career and their first song to hit the charts in both the UK and the US. It was produced by [[Ossie Byrne]] with their manager [[Robert Stigwood]] as executive producer. The song was the first track of side two on the group's international debut album, ''[[Bee Gees' 1st]].'' This was the first single with Australian drummer [[Colin Petersen]] as an official member of the band. ==Background and writing== On 3 January 1967, the Gibb brothers, with their parents and Byrne, set sail from Australia to England on the ship [[Fairsky]], reaching Southampton on 6 February. The brothers performed on board in exchange for passage. Later, the Gibb brothers auditioned for Stigwood; they passed, and they signed to [[RSO Records|Robert Stigwood Organisation]] on 24 February. "New York Mining Disaster 1941" was their first song that was written in 1967. The first recording session of the Bee Gees after returning to England was a second version of "[[Town of Tuxley Toymaker, Part 1]]," a song recorded by [[Billy J. Kramer|Billy J. Kramer and the Dakotas]], but was first recorded by Jon Blanchfield in Australia. Kramer's version was recorded on 4 March 1967 in [[IBC Studios]], London, with the Gibb brothers on background vocals. Barry and Robin Gibb wrote the song while sitting on a darkened staircase at [[Polydor Records]] following a power cut. The echo of the passing lift inspired them to imagine that they were trapped in a mine.{{cite web|url=http://www.songfacts.com/detail.php?id=7494 |title=New York Mining Disaster 1941 (Songfacts) |publisher=Songfacts |accessdate=13 March 2013}} The song recounts the story of a miner trapped in a cave-in. He is sharing a photo of his wife with a colleague ("Mr. Jones") while they hopelessly wait to be rescued.{{cite web|url= http://www.allmusic.com/song/new-york-mining-disaster-1941-mt0030257568 |title=Bee Gees - New York Mining Disaster 1941 |last=Elias |first=Jason |work=[[Allmusic]] |publisher=[[Rovi Corporation]] |accessdate=13 March 2013}} According to the liner notes for their box-set ''[[Tales from the Brothers Gibb]]'' (1990), this song was inspired by the 1966 [[Aberfan disaster|Aberfan mining disaster]] in [[Wales]]. According to Robin, there actually had also been a mining disaster in New York in 1939, but not in 1941.{{cite web|url=http://www.brothersgibb.org/history-part-4.html |title=History Part 4 - The story about the Bee Gees |last=Adriaensen |first=Marion |accessdate=13 March 2013}} In the second and third verses, the lyrical lines get slower and slower, as if to indicate that life is about to end for the miners. On the second chorus, the drums get louder. On the second verse, when Robin sings the line "I keep straining my ears to hear a sound," a violin was featured in response on Robin's line. ==Recording and composition== [[File:NYMiningdisaster68sheet.png|thumb|left|1967 sheet music cover, Abigail Music, Ltd., London. "Recorded by the Bee Gees on Polydor".]] On 7 March, the Bee Gees recorded "New York Mining Disaster 1941" in six takes, along with three other songs: "[[I Can't See Nobody]]," "Red Chair, Fade Away," and "Turn of the Century." The orchestra and some other parts were added on 13 March.{{cite web|url= http://www.columbia.edu/~brennan/beegees/67.html |title=Gibb Songs: 1967 |last=Brennan |first=Joseph |accessdate=13 March 2013}} "New York Mining Disaster 1941" was done first, and it may have already been nominated as the first single on the strength of the Polydor demo. The song begins in the chord of A minor; as Maurice explained: "There's a lot of weird sounds on this song like the Jew's harp, the string quartet, and of course the special way that Barry plays that guitar chord. Because of his tuning when he plays the minor at the beginning of the song which is different from a conventional A minor, it's a nice mixture when I play my conventional tuning together with Barry's tuning because his [[Open D tuning|open D]] and mine are different." Barry said, "It's Hawaiian tuning, there they play the same way I do. I got a guitar for my ninth birthday and the guy who lived across the road from us just came back from Hawaii and he was the one who taught me that tuning, that's how it started and I never changed." Robin Gibb took both leading and backing vocals, singing the high harmony while Barry sang the low harmony on the first and second verse: [[Maurice Gibb]] recalled in a June 2001 interview with ''[[Mojo (magazine)|Mojo]]'' magazine: "The opening chord doesn't sound like a conventional A minor. Barry was using the open D tuning he'd been taught when he was nine, and I was playing it in conventional tuning. It gives an unusual blend. People went crazy trying to figure out why they couldn't copy it." Robin Gibb recalled to ''The Mail on Sunday'' on November 1, 2009: "We recorded this at London's IBC studio because it was dark and emulated a mining shaft. The result was a very lonely sound." ==Release and reception== At the time, rumours circulated that the Bee Gees were [[The Beatles]] recording under a pseudonym (the Bee Gees' name was alleged to be code for "Beatles Group"), in part because the record referenced NEMS Enterprises ([[Brian Epstein]]'s management agency, which had just been joined by Bee Gees' manager [[Robert Stigwood]]). The song is unusual in that the lyrics do not contain the song's title, though the originally planned title, "Have You Seen My Wife, Mr. Jones," does appear in the chorus.{{cite web|url=https://digital.library.unt.edu/ark:/67531/metadc19826/m1/ |title=Show 49 - The British are Coming! The British are Coming!: With an emphasis on Donovan, the Bee Gees and the Who. (Part 6) |publisher=Unt Digital Library |accessdate=14 March 2013}} [[Atco Records|Atco]] distributed promos with a blank label and the suggestion that it was an English group whose name started with B. Many [[Disc jockey|DJ]]s thought it was a new Beatles song and played the song heavily. Atco also retitled the song "New York Mining Disaster 1941 (Have You Seen My Wife, Mr. Jones?)" to make sure people could find it in the shops.{{cite web |url=http://britishinvasionbands.com/the-bands/the-bee-gees/?doing_wp_cron=1363251960.7064080238342285156250 |title=The Bee Gees on British Invasion Bands |publisher=British Invasion |accessdate=14 March 2013 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20141022175804/http://britishinvasionbands.com/the-bands/the-bee-gees/?doing_wp_cron=1363251960.7064080238342285156250 |archivedate=22 October 2014 |df= }} [[The Beatles|Beatles]] lead guitarist [[George Harrison]] met Maurice Gibb at a party several years later, and told him that he had bought a copy of "New York Mining Disaster 1941" because he thought it sounded so much like The Beatles. Maurice's response to Harrison was that the resemblance "was unintentional" and Harrison said, "I knew that, I admire your work."{{cite book|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=KugbDQHX0R8C&pg=PT258&dq=new+york+mining+disaster+1941+they+can+tell+the+beatles&hl=fil&sa=X&ei=nuvTULrrGaeiigeQrYCAAg&ved=0CDMQ6AEwAQ |title=The Bee Gees - Tales Of The Brothers Gibb |last=Hughes |first=Andrew |accessdate=21 December 2012}} Barry Gibb explained about this song:
"If you sounded like the Beatles and also could write a hit single, then the hype of the machine would go into action, and your company would make sure people thought you sounded like the Beatles or thought you were the Beatles. And that sold you, attracted attention to you. It was good for us because everyone thought it was the Beatles under a different name."
Robin Gibb explained about this track:
"...all the DJs on radio stations in the US picked it up immediately thinking it was the Beatles, and it was a hit on that basis. It established us in those early years. It helped our following record which was nothing like the Beatles."
The success of this song owes a lot more to the perseverance of Robert Stigwood than he has previously been given credit for. "We had quite a hard time at getting the Bee Gees played. We weren't all totally convinced that Stigwood was picking the right song to plug, but at the end of the day, he was a forceful character. All of these guys were... [[Chas Chandler]] (manager of [[Jimi Hendrix]]) was the same, [[Kit Lambert]] (manager of [[The Who]]) was the same. They all argued their case with passion, you know, they lived it, they were like that," conceded [[Polydor Records|Polydor]]'s [[Alan Bates]]. When the ''Disc & Music Echo'' reported "widespread rumours" that this song had been written by [[Lennon-McCartney|Lennon and McCartney]], Robin countered with, "Rubbish! We've always written our own songs. I've been writing since I was ten, before Lennon and McCartney were even on stage. People can say what they like. If they don't believe us, they can ask The Beatles." Bassist Maurice Gibb, though, had previously said that "New York Mining Disaster 1941" was in fact influenced by the Beatles:
"New York Mining Disaster 1941" was a total rip-off of The Beatles, we were so influenced by them. In fact it started a mystery [in the USA] about us, because they started playing [it] and saying, 'They're this new group from England that begins with a B and finished with an s' so they all said, 'Ah, it's The Beatles, not naming it, they're doing that trick again.' The disc jockey would play it and play it and play it and, 'Guess who it is?' and people would guess, and they wouldn't get the answer. I heard [the idea] came actually from [[Ahmet Ertegun]] and [[Jerry Wexler]]. To us it was an honour, to actually think we were as good as The Beatles."
==Music video and live performances== On the video, the band only features four members (but [[Vince Melouney]] later joined the band), Barry playing his guitar, Maurice playing his [[Rickenbacker 4001]], Robin Gibb on vocals and drummer [[Colin Petersen]] wears a hat.{{cite web|url=https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=ps-Qq7ucMA0 |title=Bee Gees - New York Mining Disaster 1941 (1967) |publisher=You Tube |accessdate=14 July 2013}} The group found time to record their first BBC session at Playhouse Theatre, Northumberland Avenue, London, with producer Bill Bebb, on which they performed this song, with the songs "In My Own Time," "One Minute Woman," and "Cucumber Castle." When the BBC Light Programme's ''Saturday Club'' presented by Brian Matthew was broadcast on April 22, it was noted that there were "rave reviews from the audition panel." On the song's promotional clip, the band only feature four members (the three Gibb brothers and drummer [[Colin Petersen]]) The group (Barry, Robin, Maurice, Colin and Vince) made their first British TV appearance on ''Top of the Pops'' performing this song on May 11 and were rather awe-struck at the company they were keeping. On 20 May 1967, the group performed this song on ''[[Beat-Club]],'' a German TV program. The Bee Gees performed this song on 21 July 1967 at the Stockholm Palladium, Stockholm, Sweden., 12 August 1967 at The Civic Hall, Wolverhampton, England and Christ the King College at Newport, England on 27 September 1967. Since 1967, the song has been part of every Bee Gees concert, eventually becoming part of their acoustic medley performed during the middle of the concert. It was also performed on the show ''[[Beat-Club]]'' in [[Germany]], on that performance Robin wears a hat and plays [[violin]].{{cite web|url=https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=UlSLDUGKWEc |title=Bee Gees - New York Mining Disaster 1941 Live in Beat Club |publisher=You Tube |accessdate=14 July 2013}} It was performed by the group in 1973 on ''[[The Midnight Special (TV series)|The Midnight Special]]'' with Barry and Maurice on rhythm guitar.{{cite web|url=https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=hZ5tSc3tqOE |title=Bee Gees - New York Mining Disaster - live, 1973 |publisher=You Tube |accessdate=14 July 2013}} ==Personnel== * [[Robin Gibb]] – [[Lead vocalist|lead vocals]] * [[Barry Gibb]] – [[Backing vocalist|harmony]] and backing vocals, [[rhythm guitar]] * [[Maurice Gibb]] – [[bass guitar]], rhythm guitar, backing vocals * [[Colin Petersen]] – [[Drum kit|drums]] * Phil Dennys – orchestral arrangement The session was engineered by Carlos Olms and produced by Robert Stigwood. ==Charts== {{col-begin}} {{col-2}} ===Weekly charts=== {|class="wikitable sortable" |- !Chart (1967) !Peak
position |- |Australia ([[Kent Music Report]]){{cite web|url=http://www.brothersgibb.org/download/page-1.pdf |title=Songs Written by the Gibb Family on the International Charts |publisher=brothersgibb.org |accessdate=18 January 2015}} | style="text-align:center;"|11 |- |Canada Top Singles (''[[RPM (magazine)|RPM]]'') | style="text-align:center;"|34 |- |France ([[Syndicat National de l'Édition Phonographique|SNEP]]) | style="text-align:center;"|36 |- |Germany ([[Media Control Charts]]){{cite web|url=http://www.officialcharts.de/song.asp?artist=Bee+Gees&title=New+York+Mining+Disaster+1941&country=de |title=Bee Gees - New York Mining Disaster 1941 |publisher=officialcharts.de |accessdate=18 January 2015}} | style="text-align:center;"|10 |- |Netherlands ([[Dutch Top 40]]){{cite web|url=http://dutchcharts.nl/showitem.asp?interpret=Bee+Gees&titel=New+York+Mining+Disaster+1941&cat=s |title=Bee Gees - New York Mining Disaster 1941 |publisher=Dutch Charts |accessdate=18 January 2015}} | style="text-align:center;"|3 |- |New Zealand ([[Recorded Music NZ]]) | style="text-align:center;"|3 |- |UK Singles ([[Official Charts Company]]){{cite web|url=http://www.officialcharts.com/artist/_/bee%20gees/ |title=Bee Gees - Chart History |publisher=Official Charts Company |accessdate=18 January 2015}} | style="text-align:center;"|12 |- |US [[Billboard Hot 100|''Billboard'' Hot 100]]{{cite web|url=http://www.billboard.com/artist/281091/bee-gees/chart?page=4&f=379 |title=Bee Gees - Chart History |publisher=[[Billboard (magazine)|Billboard]] |accessdate=18 January 2015}} | style="text-align:center;"|14 |- |US ''[[Cashbox (magazine)|Cash Box]]''{{cite web |url=http://50.6.195.142/archives/60s_files/19670701.html |title=Cashbox Charts |date=July 1, 1967 |publisher=Cashbox Magazine Archives |accessdate=18 January 2015 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20131229202650/http://50.6.195.142/archives/60s_files/19670701.html |archivedate=29 December 2013 |df= }} | style="text-align:center;"|17 |- |US ''[[Record World]]'' | style="text-align:center;"|14 |} {{col-2}} ===Year-end charts=== {|class="wikitable sortable" |- !Chart (1967) !Position |- |Netherlands ([[Dutch Top 40]]) | style="text-align:center;"|17 |} {{col-end}} ==Legacy== The 1969 [[David Bowie]] song "[[Space Oddity]]" owes a debt to the style, arrangement and lyrics of "New York Mining Disaster 1941." Like "New York Mining Disaster 1941," "Space Oddity" is about a trapped man who is doomed to die, and the song is similarly structured as a series of statements addressed to another person. "'Space Oddity' was a Bee Gees type song," Bowie’s colleague John "Hutch" Hutchinson has said. "David knew it, and he said so at the time, the way he sang it, it’s a Bee Gees thing."{{cite web |url=http://davidbowie.com/users/lunamagic/space1.html |title=David Bowie - Space Oddity |accessdate=13 March 2013 }}{{dead link|date=February 2018 |bot=InternetArchiveBot |fix-attempted=yes }} As [[Marc Bolan]] explained: "I remember David playing me 'Space Oddity' in his room and I loved it and he said he needed a sound like the Bee Gees, who were very big then." [[Paul McCartney]] said: "It was the 'Mining Disaster' song that [Robert Stigwood] played me. I said 'sign them, they're great!' And they went on to be even greater."{{cite web |url=http://www14.brinkster.com/corteza/bg/citas.htm |title=Bee Gees |publisher=14.brinkster.com |accessdate=2014-04-07 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20131230235737/http://www14.brinkster.com/corteza/bg/citas.htm |archivedate=2013-12-30 |df= }} The Japanese Novelist [[Haruki Murakami]] made "New York Mining Disaster" the title of one of his short stories. The piece was included in his collection "[[Blind Willow, Sleeping Woman]]".{{cite web|last=Umrigar |first=Thrity |url=http://www.boston.com/ae/books/articles/2006/10/01/murakami_pulls_mind_bending_stories_from_the_ruins_of_broken_rules/ |title=Murakami pulls mind-bending stories from the ruins of broken rules - The Boston Globe |website=Boston.com |date=2006-10-01 |accessdate=2016-07-27}} ==Cover versions== * In early 1969, [[The Sorrows]] recorded this song as part of a demo album that was prepared before the release of their second album ''Old Songs New Songs''; however, the song remained unreleased until it was included in a two-CD reissue of that album by Wooden Hill in 2009. * In 1969, [[Ashton, Gardner and Dyke]] recorded a version of this song for their self-titled debut album. * In 1974, [[Barclay James Harvest]] "deconstructed" the song with a reworked version referencing leading figures in the [[Three-Day Week|1974 UK mining strike]]. The song was retitled "The Great 1974 Mining Disaster."{{cite web|url=http://www.songfacts.com/detail.php?id=8023 |title=The Great 1974 Mining Disaster by Barclay James Harvest Songfacts |publisher=Songfacts.com |date= |accessdate=2014-04-07}} * In 1993, [[David Essex]] recorded a version of this song for his covers album ''Cover Shot.'' * In 1997, the [[Levellers (band)|Levellers]] covered the song as a B-side to their single ''Bozos.'' * In 1998, folksinger [[Martin Carthy]] sang an acoustic guitar version of this as the lead-off track on his album ''Signs of Life.'' * In 2000, British anarchist band [[Chumbawamba]] recorded a "[[minimalist]]" version for their album ''[[WYSIWYG (album)|WYSIWYG]].'' * In 2006, Mark Newman recorded a version of "New York Mining Disaster, 1941" on his CD ''Must Be A Pony,'' which he released on Danal Music. * In 2008, singer-songwriter [[Trevor Tanner]] released a version titled ''Mr. Jones'' on his album ''Eaten By The Sea.'' * In 2011, Australian bush punk act Handsome Young Strangers covered the song as a B-side to their single ''Sweet As A Nut'' and then included it on their album ''Here's The Thunder Lads!'' * In 2011 British Folk artist [[Jon Boden]] (of folk big Band [[Bellowhead]]) released an unaccompanied version as part of his "A Folk Song a Day" Project. * In 2012, the Catalina Scramblers, a three-piece rock band from Santa Cruz, CA, recorded a version of the song in which they adhere to the original version's style for the verses, but perform the choruses in up-tempo, hard rock fashion. It was released as the final track on their eponymous debut album. ==References== {{Reflist|30em}} ==External links== *{{YouTube|ps-Qq7ucMA0|Official music video of the song}} *[http://www.brothersgibb.org/history-part-4.html History of the song] *[https://www.rollingstone.com/reviews/album/13716838/review/13750860/the_studio_albums_19671968 Rolling Stone Review] *[{{Allmusic|class=song|id=t3116604|pure_url=yes}} AMG Review] * {{MetroLyrics song|bee-gees|new-york-mining-disaster-1941}} {{Bee Gees}} {{Bee Gees singles}} [[Category:Bee Gees songs]] [[Category:1967 singles]] [[Category:1967 songs]] [[Category:Songs about New York (state)]] [[Category:Songs written by Barry Gibb]] [[Category:Songs written by Robin Gibb]] [[Category:Song recordings produced by Robert Stigwood]] [[Category:Folk rock songs]] [[Category:Polydor Records singles]] [[Category:Atco Records singles]] [[Category:Spin Records (Australian label) singles]] [[Category:Songs based on actual events]] [[Category:Works about mining]]

'''Non-aqueous phase liquids''' or '''NAPLs''' are [[liquid solution]] [[contaminant]]s that do not dissolve in or easily mix with water ([[hydrophobic]]), like [[oil]], [[gasoline]] and [[petroleum]] products.<ref>National Research Council, 1994</ref>
NAPLs tend to [[soil contamination|contaminate soil]] and [[groundwater contamination|groundwaters]].<ref name="chezch">{{cite journal|last1=Konečný F, Boháček Z, Müller P, Kovářová and M, Sedláčková|title=Contamination of soils and groundwater by petroleum hydrocarbons and volatile organic compounds...|journal=Bulletin of Geosciences|date=2003|volume=78|issue=3|page=1214|url=http://www.geology.cz/bulletin/fulltext/bulgeosci200303225.pdf|accessdate=May 27, 2017}}</ref><ref name="dnals">{{cite web|last1=Huling, Scott and Weaver, James|title=Dense Nonaquieous Liquids|url=https://www.epa.gov/sites/production/files/2015-06/documents/dnapl_issue_paper.pdf|website=Ground Water Issue|publisher=Environmental Protection Agency|accessdate=May 27, 2017|date=1991}}</ref> Many common groundwater contaminants such as [[chlorinated]] solvents and many petroleum products enter the subsurface in nonaqueous-phase solutions.<ref>National Research Council, 1993</ref> They do not mix readily with water and therefore flow separately from ground water.<ref>National Research Council, 1997</ref>
If the NAPL is denser than water, like [[trichloroethylene]], it is called [[DNAPL]] and will tend to sink once it reaches the water table. If it is lighter, like gasoline, it is called [[LNAPL]] and will tend to float on the water table. <ref>National Research Council, 1997</ref> DNAPL penetrates below the water table like ice cubes in a glass of water. {{Inconsistent|date=August 2018}}<ref>Interstate Regulatory Technology Council, 2015</ref>
== Notes == <References/>
== See also == * [[DNAPL]] * [[LNAPL]]
== External links == * [http://toxics.usgs.gov Toxic Substances Hydrology Program] from the [[USGS]]
== References == * National Research Council, 1997, [http://books.nap.edu/openbook.php?record_id=5781&page=R1 Innovations in ground water and soil cleanup--From concept to commercialization]: Washington, D.C., National Academies Press, 310 p. * National Research Council, 1994, [http://www.nap.edu/openbook.php?isbn=0309049946 Alternatives for ground water cleanup]: Washington, D.C., National Academies Press, 315 p. * National Research Council, 1993, [http://www.nap.edu/openbook.php?isbn=0309048966 In situ bioremediation--When does it work?]: Washington, D.C., National Academies Press, 224 p. {{Watersupply-stub}} [[Category:Organochlorides]] [[Category:Water chemistry]] [[Category:Hydrogeology]] [[Category:Water pollution]]

'''Orthopterology''' (from [[Ancient Greek]] {{lang|el|[[wikt:ὀρθός|ὀρθός]]}} (straight) and {{lang|el|[[wikt:πτερόν|πτερόν]]}} (wing); and {{lang|grc|-λογία}} ''[[-logy|-logia]]''.), is the scientific study of the order [[Orthoptera]], which includes [[grasshopper]]s, [[cricket (insect)|crickets]], [[locust]]s and other insects. Someone that studies in this field is a '''orthopterist'''.
==Orthopterology as a science== A notable subgroup of orthopterology is '''Acridology''', which focuses on locusts and grasshoppers in the family [[Acrididae]], in the efforts of famine prevention.<ref name="test">[http://www.uwyo.edu/esm/grasshoppers/aaai/index.html]</ref>
==Orthopterological societies== * Association for Applied Acridology International * [[Orthopterists' Society]] * [[German Society for Orthopterology]]
==Orthopterological Journals== * [[Journal of Orthoptera Research]]
==See also== * [[LUBILOSA]]
==References== <references />
==External links== *[https://web.archive.org/web/20050615144819/http://www.affa.gov.au/content/output.cfm?ObjectID=D2C48F86-BA1A-11A1-A2200060B0A00383 Australian Plague Locust Commission] *[http://www.orthoptera.org/ The Orthopterists' Society] *[http://www.acrida.info AcridAfrica, les acridiens d'Afrique de l'Ouest]
{{Entomology}} {{zoology|African.field.cricket.arp.jpg|expanded=Branches}}
[[Category:Subfields of entomology]] [[Category:Orthoptera]]
{{Orthoptera-stub}}

'''Peculiar motion''' or '''peculiar velocity''' refers to the [[velocity]] of an object relative to a [[rest frame]] — usually a frame in which the average velocity of some objects is zero.
[[Image:Galaxy supercluster peculiar motion.png|right|thumb|375px|A map of galaxy supercluster peculiar motion]]
== Galactic astronomy ==
In [[galactic astronomy]], '''peculiar motion''' refers to the motion of an object (usually a [[star]]) relative to a Galactic rest frame.
Local objects are often related in terms of [[proper motion]] and [[radial velocity]], which can be combined through [[Vector (spatial)|vector addition]] to produce the object's motion relative to the [[Sun]]. Velocities for local objects are sometimes reported with respect to the [[local standard of rest]] (LSR) — the average local motion of material in the galaxy — instead of the Sun's rest frame. Translating between the LSR and heliocentric rest frames requires the calculation of the Sun's peculiar velocity in the LSR.<ref name=mnras403> {{cite journal |last1=Schönrich |first1=R. |last2=Binney |first2=J. |date=2010 |title=Local kinematics and the local standard of rest |journal=[[Monthly Notices of the Royal Astronomical Society]] |volume=403 |issue=4 |pages=1829–1833 |arxiv=0912.3693 |bibcode=2010MNRAS.403.1829S |bibcode-access=free |doi=10.1111/j.1365-2966.2010.16253.x |doi-access=free }}</ref>
== Cosmology ==
In [[physical cosmology]], '''peculiar velocity''' refers to the components of a [[galaxy]]'s velocity that deviate from the [[Hubble's law|Hubble flow]]. According to Hubble's Law, galaxies recede from us at speeds proportional to their distance from us.
Galaxies are not distributed evenly throughout observable space, but are typically found in groups or [[galaxy cluster|clusters]], where they have a significant [[gravitation|gravitational]] effect on each other. [[velocity dispersion|Velocity dispersions]] of galaxies arising from this gravitational attraction are usually in the hundreds of kilometers per second, but they can rise to over 1000 km/s in rich clusters.<ref name=Girardi93> {{cite journal |last1=Girardi |first1=M. |last2=Biviano |first2=A. |last3=Giuricin |first3=G. |last4=Mardirossian |first4=F. |last5=Mezzetti |first5=M. |year=1993 |title=Velocity dispersions in galaxy clusters |journal=[[The Astrophysical Journal]] |volume=404 |pages=38–50 |bibcode=1993ApJ...404...38G |bibcode-access=free |doi=10.1086/172256 |doi-access=free }}</ref> This velocity can alter the [[recessional velocity]] that would be expected from the Hubble flow and effect the observed [[redshift]] of objects via the [[relativistic Doppler effect]]. The Doppler redshift due to peculiar velocities is :<math>1+z_{pec}=\sqrt{\frac{1+v/c}{1-v/c}}</math>
which is approximately :<math>z \approx v/c </math>
for low velocities (small redshifts). This combines with the redshift from the Hubble flow to give the observed redshift<ref name=Davis11/> :<math>1+z_{obs} = (1+z_{pec})(1+z_{H}).</math>
The radial velocity of an object can be approximated by :<math>v_{r} = H_0 d + v_{pec}</math>
with contributions from both the Hubble flow and peculiar velocity terms, where <math>H_0</math> is the Hubble constant and <math>d</math> is the distance to the object.
[[Redshift-space distortions]] can cause the spacial distributions of cosmological objects to appear elongated or flattened out, depending on the cause of the peculiar velocities.<ref name=Kaiser87> {{cite journal |last1=Kaiser |first1=N. |year=1987 |title=Clustering in real space and in redshift space |journal=[[Monthly Notices of the Royal Astronomical Society]] |volume=227 |issue=1 |pages=1–21 |bibcode=1987MNRAS.227....1K |bibcode-access=free |doi=10.1093/mnras/227.1.1 |doi-access=free }}</ref> Elongation, sometimes referred to as the "Fingers of God" effect, is caused by random thermal motion of objects; however, correlated peculiar velocities from gravitational infall are the cause of a flattening effect.<ref name=Percival11> {{cite journal |last1=Percival |first1=W. J. |last2=Samushia |first2=L. |last3=Ross |first3=A. J. |last4=Shapiro |first4=C. |last5=Raccanelli |first5=A. |year=2011 |title=Redshift-space distortions |journal=[[Philosophical Transactions of the Royal Society A]] |volume=369 |issue=1957 |pages=5058–5067 |bibcode=2011RSPTA.369.5058P |doi=10.1098/rsta.2011.0370 |doi-access=free }}</ref> The main consequence is that, in determining the distance of a single galaxy, a possible error must be assumed. This error becomes smaller as distance increases. For example, in surveys of type Ia [[supernova|supernovae]], peculiar velocities have a significant influence on measurements out to redshifts around 0.5, leading to errors of several percent when calculating cosmological parameters.<ref name=Davis11> {{cite journal |last1=Davis |first1=T. M. |last2=Hui |first2=L. |last3=Frieman |first3=J. A. |last4=Haugbølle |first4=T. |last5=Kessler |first5=R. |last6=Sinclair |first6=B. |last7=Sollerman |first7=J. |last8=Bassett |first8=B. |last9=Marriner |first9=J. |last10=Mörtsell |first10=E. |last11=Nichol |first11=R. C. |last12=Richmond |first12=M. W. |last13=Sako |first13=M. |last14=Schneider |first14=D. P. |last15=Smith |first15=M. |year=2011 |title=The Effect of Peculiar Velocities on Supernova Cosmology |journal=[[The Astrophysical Journal]] |volume=741 |pages=67 |arxiv=1012.2912 |bibcode=2011ApJ...741...67D |bibcode-access=free |doi=10.1088/0004-637X/741/1/67 |doi-access=free }}</ref><ref name=Sugiura99> {{cite journal |last1=Sugiura |first1=N. |last2=Sugiyama |first2=N. |last3=Sasaki |first3=M. |year=1999 |title=Anisotropies in Luminosity Distance |url=https://academic.oup.com/ptp/article-lookup/doi/10.1143/PTP.101.903 |journal=[[Progress of Theoretical Physics]] |volume=101 |issue=4 |pages=903–922 |bibcode=1999PThPh.101..903S |doi=10.1143/ptp.101.903 |doi-access=free }}</ref>
Peculiar velocities can also contain useful information about the universe. The connection between correlated peculiar velocities and mass distribution has been suggested as a tool for determining constraints for cosmological parameters using peculiar velocity surveys.<ref name=Odderskov17> {{cite journal |last1=Odderskov |first1=I. |last2=Hannestad |first2=S. |date=1 January 2017 |title=Measuring the velocity field from type Ia supernovae in an LSST-like sky survey |journal=[[Journal of Cosmology and Astroparticle Physics]] |volume=1 |pages=60 |arxiv=1608.04446 |bibcode=2017JCAP...01..060O |doi=10.1088/1475-7516/2017/01/060 }}</ref><ref name=Weinberg13> {{cite journal |last1=Weinberg |first1=D. H. |last2=Mortonson |first2=M. J. |last3=Eisenstein |first3=D. J. |last4=Hirata |first4=C. |last5=Riess |first5=A. G. |last6=Rozo |first6=E. |year=2013 |title=Observational probes of cosmic acceleration |journal=[[Physics Reports]] |volume=530 |issue=2 |pages=87–255 |arxiv=1201.2434 |bibcode=2013PhR...530...87W |doi=10.1016/j.physrep.2013.05.001 }}</ref>
